content.question: The structural formulas of two compounds that are liquids at room temperature are shown above. Which of the following statements best explains the observation that compound 1 boils at <math alttext="35 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mn>35</mn></mpadded><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, whereas its structural isomer, compound 2, boils at <math alttext="118 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>118</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>?

choices.label: Molecules of compound 1 have a linear shape and no net dipole, whereas molecules of compound 2 have a bent shape and are polar.
Molecules of compound 1 are bent less than molecules of compound 2; thus they have weaker dipole-dipole attractions.
There are dipole-dipole attractions among molecules of compound 1, whereas there are only dispersion forces among molecules of compound 2.

Although there are dipole-dipole attractions among molecules of both compound 1 and compound 2, the <math alttext="O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>OH</mi></mpadded></math> group in compound 2 allows strong hydrogen bonding to occur.

content.answer: Although there are dipole-dipole attractions among molecules of both compound 1 and compound 2, the <math alttext="O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>OH</mi></mpadded></math> group in compound 2 allows strong hydrogen bonding to occur.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
